text: Activity of the kappa B enhancer of the <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 receptor alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> chain in somatic cell hybrids is accompanied by the nuclear localization of NF-kappa B .

The two nuclear proteins NF-kappa B ( consisting of subunits <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> p65 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) and the DNA - binding subunit of NF-kappa B ( <extra_id_0> p50 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) by itself , also called <extra_id_0> KBF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> , are constitutively expressed and localized in the nucleus of the human T-cell line IARC 301.5 .

text: In order to define the roles of these two factors , which bind to the same kappa B enhancers , in transcription activation we have prepared somatic cell hybrids between IARC 301.5 and a murine myeloma .
Most hybrids express both <extra_id_0> KBF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and NF-kappa B in their nuclei , but one hybrid expresses only <extra_id_0> KBF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> .

text: The kappa B enhancer of the gene encoding the <extra_id_0> interleukin-2 (IL-2) receptor alpha chain <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ( <extra_id_0> IL-2R alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> ) is functional only in the hybrids expressing nuclear NF-kappa B .
These findings show that nuclear NF-kappa B is necessary to activate the kappa B enhancer , while <extra_id_0> KBF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> by itself is not sufficient .

We propose that <extra_id_0> KBF1 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> is a competitive inhibitor of NF-kappa B and discuss how these factors may be involved in the transient expression of <extra_id_0> IL-2 <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> and <extra_id_0> IL-2R alpha <extra_id_2> Protein <extra_id_1> genes during the immune response .
